0.text: Thank you for the opportunity to be here and especially for it to be

6.text: during anti poverty week and I want to say a bit about that in a moment.  But perhaps to

12.text: emphasise that I don't really approach this topic mainly as an academic in

17.text: the area because I'm not, I've been mainly for the last 15 or 20 years only part-time

25.text: as a professor, but more an advocate or a co ordinator of cross sexual

30.text: groups in the community pushing for reform and housing change.  So I'm drawing a fair

34.text: bit on the sort of, practical experience either when I was the head of a welfare

40.text: rights centre right at the coalface or working closely with those people. But it

46.text: is anti poverty week so I hope you'll excuse me if I just say a little bit about that because we

49.text: established that 15 odd years ago at the University of New South Wales at the social

55.text: justice project that I'm the head of.  And it really arose from my

60.text: experience - I'd just finished then as the head of the international council on

63.text: social welfare and was aware of some of the activities developing around the

68.text: international anti poverty day, which is October 17 - and although I'm not over the moon

74.text: about days and things of that kind, they can be more tokenistic than anything else,

80.text: it seemed to me that there was value in developing and particularly, to try and

84.text: get beyond the charmed circle of the usual suspects of people who speak about

89.text: poverty issues. My own view, and I think the experience of anti poverty week

93.text: confirms this, is that there are more people than the media and the many in

97.text: politics believe in Australia who are deeply concerned about poverty,

101.text: especially from their own personal experience of people around them.

105.text: Not necessarily themselves being in poverty, but people who move in those communities

109.text: where people are severely disadvantaged or at least to some extent, are still visible.

115.text: But it's important not to preach to them, not to tell them what they should think

122.text: about poverty too much and certainly not what should be done about it,

126.text: and to encourage them to feel part of a broader movement

128.text: to try and reduce poverty without having to sign up for any particular ideological framework.

132.text: And also not to exaggerate to them the nature of the hardship that we have.

139.text: And so anti poverty week itself has remained fiercely, rather like just

146.text: hiring a hall and saying anyone can come and turn up their stall.

150.text: And one of my roles is the National Chair, which I've been from the beginning, is actually to stop it,

154.text: as it were, being taken over by any particular policy or approach.

158.text: It's got to be a broad church.  That's sometimes misunderstood by some,

162.text: but of course while participating in anti poverty week one can say whatever one likes.

166.text: One can push as much of a policy line as one wants, but it's important that the week itself,

170.text: as a process, as a week, is available to everyone.

175.text: And we've grown from the first year when we had five activities all run by people whose arms

180.text: had been severely bent by me to the last four years we've had more than

185.text: 450 around Australia and I think we'll have the same number this year.  And just to give

189.text: you an indication of the breadth of it, read from the national media alert we

192.text: put out at the end of last week about the types of activities;

195.text: launches, forums, workshops, awards, exhibitions, walks, fundraisers, publications,

201.text: presentation, addresses, festivals; a huge festival in Forrest Place in Perth this year as it was last year.

206.text: And the venues include; shopping centres, parks,

211.text: cathedrals, community centres, libraries, hotels, health centres, welfare agencies,

216.text: business offices, town halls, parliaments, universities, schools, car parks, squares and markets;

221.text: and we've had some even more out there alternative venues in previous years.

227.text: You may have seen there have been some reports or strategies already released

233.text: and one of them was particularly relevant here is Anglicare State of the Family report,

237.text: which they release each year during anti poverty week.  This year we've also got

243.text: Salvation Army report and a report on poverty and disadvantage from the

249.text: Western Australia and many others.  So I hope if you haven't already been

253.text: involved with anti poverty week that you might take the opportunity in the future.

256.text: I should say it's spread now to Scotland first, about two or three years ago, and it's now spread to the

263.text: United States.  Anyway, that's a digression, but I hope a legitimate one to try to

270.text: emphasise the importance of anti poverty week since we're meeting during that week.

275.text: Now I want to turn now to the main theme, which is housing, transport and family

280.text: problems whether poverty or hardship or of other kinds and in doing that, I want to

289.text: look at aspects of the impact of the family home; so that's cost and adequacy and security;

296.text: and of the family location, the choice they may have about location,

302.text: problems relating to family relationships and health and some

306.text: broader public impacts.  And then I'll look at some options for action.

312.text: Deliberately, some of them not in the mainstream of what many people who

319.text: are working specifically on family issues focus on.  I firmly believe that those

325.text: of us who are concerned about social justice, many of us anyway, not everyone, but many

329.text: of us need to address ourselves to the deeper underlying causes very often,

334.text: particularly in relation to economic issues, not to regard economic issues as either

338.text: beyond us or beneath us because very often otherwise, frankly, we're just sort of

343.text: trying to swim upstream trying to reduce some of the damage of the deeper

347.text: underlying environments and economic settings and public policy settings that

351.text: are causing the problems. So I'm going to look at tax reform in relation to the

356.text: principal residences.  I deliberately don't call it the family home because

361.text: increasingly things that are called the family home are really tax shelters and

365.text: it's being a little too kind to them to call them family homes.  So it's principal residences;

373.text: some issues to do with transport.  And then public planning and investment;

378.text:
regional cities, housing and transport.  
Some underlying concerns before doing that,

387.text: just very briefly.  Firstly, to an extent that I think a few people in

393.text: Australia realise or are willing to admit, we're a highly vulnerable economy.  When it

397.text: happens people are going to say no one believed it was going to happen.  I don't

401.text: really understand why.  We've been saved for a decade or so by China, but the

407.text: underlying problems with our economy will come out eventually.  One can't say

411.text: exactly when, but I'm sure they will.  We're a very small economy, we're very remote,

416.text: both in distance and in some ways, in culture from the countries that are

420.text: near us and we're very heavily dependent on commodities.  And increasingly,

425.text: the extent to which we are able to make a living in the world, as it were,

428.text: through services we will be subject to much more competition from Asia.

434.text: We have very low levels of public investment even though we're a country,

439.text: which is one of the fastest growing in population in the developed world.  We're still a relatively

443.text: new country in terms of so-called western development and we have big distances.

450.text: You'd expect us to have an above average level of public infrastructure

454.text: investment amongst developed countries; in fact, it's very low.  We have weakening work

459.text: opportunities hidden to some extent by the fact, the extent to which it's

464.text: underemployment rather than total unemployment.  But the total supply just

470.text: in terms of supply let alone quality, which I'll come to in a moment of

474.text: employment, is weakening. We have, as I think,

480.text: both ACOSS and Anglicare have shown this week,

482.text: increasing financial inequality, but I want to emphasise many

487.text: of the studies tend to focus on income inequality and that's significant, but asset

493.text: inequality is far worse.  It's a factor of five to ten times worse,

500.text: the inequality in relation to assets and getting worse with every passing month.  And I think

506.text: asset inequality is hugely overlooked both within the social justice sector,

511.text: if I can put it that way, and also more broadly. We have heightened social tensions,

517.text: I believe, partly religiously related, partly to do with this growing

522.text: inequality and divide that I'll say a bit more about later and I'm afraid I think also

526.text: we will have heightened race base social tensions in the future.  I think we have to

531.text: be brutally realistic about that.  We have accelerating climate change in a country

537.text: that's particularly vulnerable to it because of our underlying climate anyway,

542.text: but secondly, amongst many factors, dependency on coal. We have a highly concentrated population

550.text: and I'll come back to that later, and I think we suffer form particularly poorly

555.text: informed public discussion by comparison with many other developed countries.

559.text: Partly because of the tendency for the media to become increasingly sensationalist,

562.text: increasingly pushing material out in haste without having

567.text: thought about it or checked it sufficiently; and also a growing tendency

572.text: towards polarisation especially in the mainstream media as they seek to find

576.text: fellow travelling markets in order to try and remain commercially viable.

583.text: So those are some of the underlying concerns, but I want to move on now to problems

587.text: relating to the family home.  I'm not going to dwell on some of them because I think

591.text: they're very well known, but prices and rent are much higher relative to

595.text: incomes than in the past and extraordinarily high even by international standards and

601.text: that's comparing it to household income.  And when you bear in mind that household

608.text: middle to higher is two-earner income where a few decades ago it was only one-earner income,

614.text: it shows you that this has gone up by far more than just real terms because household

618.text: disposable income has gone up a lot ahead of inflation over that longer

624.text: period as women, in particular, have come into the paid workforce. And that means

629.text: of course that sole parents and other single-income families are particularly

632.text: falling behind.  These prices and rents may plateau and I'm afraid the media will then

640.text: believe the problem has gone.  They may even fall slightly and again the problem,

644.text: the media would be, and others, would be very ill-advised I think, to think that

648.text: the problem has gone, but I'm afraid that's the way things often operate.

653.text: We are already and have been for a long time at deeply damaging levels of house

657.text: prices and rents.  Damaging not only for the people who have to pay them, but also

662.text: for the broader economic development of the country, which I'll come to later.

667.text: And of course, it's aggravated by the fact that public housing is not keeping pace

672.text: with increases in the size of the population let alone increases in the populations that

678.text: formerly would've been able to get into it and needed it. We've got increasing

682.text: dependents on parental support in order to get into the housing market.  Now that may,

688.text: to some extent funnily enough, overcome some of the massive problems of

692.text: intergenerational inequity that are arising from the sort of, baby boomer generation in a sense.

698.text: At least some of their ill-gotten gains are being passed on to help their

703.text:
children this way but that's that's fine
for those who've got parents again lucky

707.text: or wise, but in many cases it's really luck, and have that gain to pass on.

714.text: So it's actually aggravating very severely inherited inequity, which is one of the

718.text: worst forms of inequity and I think it's a huge social problem.

723.text: Some of us have been pointing that out vainly for 20 years because none of this is really new,

726.text: it's just become even more acute.  But it's been a major problem and clearly was going to become worse

733.text: from 20 years ago. There's greater difficulty in meeting other basic costs of course.

738.text: Housing is the largest expenditure for most families and it's

741.text: the first in a sense.  It's the one that they really have to pay and they'll go

744.text: without almost everything else including food, in order to keep the home over their heads.

752.text: And therefore, it has flow-on impacts to food, to clothing, to school trips, to health costs.

758.text: I saw Andrew Leigh, the MP who wrote a really wonderful speech for Anglicare

765.text: Australia national conference recently, who says - and I'm sure he's right because he says

769.text: so meticulous - that lower income people have seven less teeth than higher income people,

775.text: just because of the disparities in their ability to have dental care.

782.text: So these are sort of deeply, deeply brutal every day life problems that are

786.text: caused by the high housing costs, but also I think for the first time really

791.text: at least in my experience, it's now reasonable to say that much of the cause

797.text: of homelessness is housing costs.  I don't think that was the case ten or 20 years ago.

802.text: There were usually other factors that were far more prominent than the actually cost of housing.

807.text: But I think now it's fair to say that unaffordability of housing is a

814.text: really, quite substantial and growing factor in the problems of homelessness.

818.text: We have very high household debt in Australia - I'll come back to that again later -

825.text: and we're diverting national resources into just bidding up house prices against each other.

830.text: National resources, which could've gone into job producing

833.text: enterprises or into enterprises which would reduce our trade deficit, but all they do

838.text: is pay more and more money for, by and large, a product that isn't much better than when

845.text: the price was very much lower. I'll move on then to problems of adequacy.

857.text: We have larger houses for many families and of course, that's one of the things

864.text: that's commented upon by people who say, well house prices are going up,

869.text: that's because housing is so large and we are over providing housing;

873.text: people have excessive housing expectations. I think to the extent that my view is relevant,

879.text: that is true that quite a lot of housing that's been provided for people now is pretty

883.text: much over the top.  I've been looking at some recently where there is sort of as many as

886.text: three or four sort of entertainment theatres or multimedia places, that sort of thing,

893.text: in a fairly standard house.  They are getting very big for middle income,

898.text: but the biggest problem in house prices is not the construction of a house by

906.text: a long shot, it's the land.  So those who worry about the cost of building,

910.text: okay, it may be that you know, some of the houses are a little over the top,

915.text: but that's not really a significant impact in the broad scheme of things

920.text: in house prices, it's the land. And one problem that flows from that of course

925.text: is that's why you'll tend to have huge McMansions on tiny blocks

930.text: and when you look inside those McMansions quite often, there'll be hardly any furniture.

934.text: Furniture isn't a tax break, the house is.  I was telling that story,

943.text: from my experience, about furniture to someone the other day who works at the frontline

947.text: and she said that their workers often notice when they go to some

952.text: of those McMansions that when they turn up, there sort of might be one light on

958.text: in the house, even though there are lots of people in it.  They're having to save on energy

962.text: costs and that sort of thing.  So huge amount of money gone into the house, it's a tax break;

966.text: furniture and use of energy is not. There are more families whose only option is an apartment.

975.text: I think this is a huge problem.  Of course apartments are very desirable or at least

980.text: neutral for many people, but for many others I think exactly the opposite,

986.text: and the data and research tends to suggest particularly high-rise apartments have

990.text: major problems especially for people with youngish children.  They can be bad

997.text: for the family relationships through being on top of each other too much without

1001.text: sufficient space and privacy and access to outside; adverse impacts on health

1006.text: because of the reduced exercise; and adverse impacts on the ability,

1011.text: for example, to study and further one's education. Now of course that's not always the case.

1015.text: Some apartments can be better than some detached or semi detached houses,

1020.text: but we need to be very careful, I think, of believing that apartments are the answer

1026.text: and especially you find, as I've seen over the years

1030.text: repeatedly happens in the housing industry, where they say, this is

1033.text: what people want.  They only want it because it's all they can afford in many cases.

1038.text: Some do want it.  I've lived in apartments during my time and they've been what I've wanted to live in

1043.text: at the time.  But you know, I had the money to be in a reasonable apartment,

1051.text: but it's quite misleading to say that just because people are buying apartments that's what

1054.text: they want and that's a sufficient response to their concerns.  And Melbourne,

1059.text: apart from anything else, is as good a place as any to learn the problems of high rise

1064.text: apartments for low income people.  I thought that lesson had been learnt,

1068.text: but I'm not too sure it has been in the longer term,

1072.text: at least by people in treasury.

1074.text: More adult children, as you know, now are staying at home.  Now they're not staying out of love,

1083.text: by and large, they're staying because of their wallet.  This, I think, is aggravating problems

1088.text: of friction and lack of privacy in many cases and also, it may be what some

1094.text: people commented on as a sort of prolonged adolescence or a slowness in becoming independent.

1100.text: I don't just mean in relation to housing, but in other ways.  Again, you could regard

1107.text: this as the baby boomers getting back what they deserve from having

1113.text: children around longer than they want, but that's really not helping either

1119.text: side of the equation. And it's also leading, in many cases, to parents staying

1124.text: in a larger house even after the children have left.  Larger houses than they need

1128.text: and that they want in many cases, because they can't be sure whether the children will in fact,

1132.text: in the current housing market, want or need to come back.  And as you may

1138.text: know since I'm in that sort of generation where my children are about that age,

1140.text: it's a very common occurrence that they were to come back into their

1145.text: parents' house even if they've left it at the age of 30 or even older because of

1150.text: the current housing environment. And also high, particularly cooling costs for many lower income

1157.text: people through very poor housing design.  It astounds me how we've allowed

1164.text: I always have problems with climatic and climactic, but here I mean climatic -

1169.text: for our climate to be building houses without eaves and in other ways,

1177.text: so much dependent upon air conditioning is really crazy and has

1183.text: been a major factor in the over investment in generating plants and

1189.text: therefore the increase in electricity prices. Well I'll move on to the last of the

1194.text: areas to do with problems with the family home and that's security.

1197.text: Work incomes now are often less secure.  This again is a problem in the work environment,

1203.text: which I think is not sufficiently picked up by many economists

1206.text: and others who just tend to look at raw figures and at moments in time figures

1209.text: and don't realise that particularly for younger people now,

1215.text: so much work is so precarious.  Some younger people are at the stage where they relish that.

1218.text: They see it as freedom and flexibility to be an entrepreneur et cetera, et cetera.

1221.text: I may be wrong, but I think quite a lot of them are going to find

1226.text: that life's very difficult later on when they want a greater degree of security for one

1229.text: reason or another.  But in any event, the 7 Eleven experience is actually pretty

1238.text: widespread for many young people, as you probably know.  Highly exploitative employer

1245.text: behaviour, not only in relation to low wages, but also in relation to the risks

1251.text: of any downturn, even the fact that not many people turn up at the beginning of

1255.text: a four hour shift so that the person gets told to go home and not paid for the

1259.text: remaining three hours of the shift they come in for, that kind of behaviour is not that uncommon.

1263.text: As part of the general transfer that's occurred in the last 20 years

1267.text: of the risks of business downturn, even short business downturn,

1271.text: being transferred right at the front end to workers, rather than carried by the

1276.text: business itself for a reasonable period. Fewer homes fully or largely paid off.

1282.text: As you know, it's still the case that very often data about housing talks about

1287.text: home ownership and homeowners when some of them are home purchasers, they may have only just started buying.

1293.text: Now for a long while, perhaps it didn't matter in one sense, because

1297.text: they were all going to become full homeowners and nearly all of them pretty soon.  But now it's very

1301.text: important to distinguish, it's probably five or six years ago that the tipping point,

1307.text: in a sense, occurred when more than 50 per cent of people in buying their homes

1313.text: were still buying rather than fully owning.  Before that, it was a much higher proportion.

1317.text: So many are still paying off and of course, now we have

1322.text: interest only loans so many people haven't really even started paying off at all.

1326.text: It's said that superannuation will be part of an answer to this in that instead of in

1333.text: the past, being fully paid off when you go into retirement, you won't be fully paid off,

1336.text: but you'll help super to help pay the mortgage.  And there's some truth in that,

1341.text: but superannuation is not entirely risk free.  Again, this is another example of the

1346.text: trend in the last 20 years to transfer risk from public or employer locuses

1352.text: to the worker or the consumer. And superannuation, we haven't fully realised yet,

1359.text: I think, we had a short period in the global financial crisis,

1363.text: that superannuation is not actually a golden egg and in any event, just paying out, seeing whether

1371.text: superannuation will last through your unknown lifespan is very different from

1375.text: having fully paid off your house. The increasing dependence of low income

1383.text: families on insecure private rental, I think that's pretty widely known so I won't dwell on it,

1387.text: but of course it's been exaggerated by the relative decline and the

1391.text: availability of public housing.  It's also a consequence to some extent of one of

1396.text: the many ways in which Australia is a real outlier, as it were, in the world in the housing area.

1400.text: I don't know if any area of policy where we're actually so unusual by world

1405.text: standards as housing.  And one of the ways in which we're unusual is what, to people

1410.text: overseas is a quite freakish level of so-called mum and dad

1414.text: investment in property.  Of course it's no longer mum and dad. No other country

1420.text: is remotely near us in terms of the amount of the rental stock, which is owned by

1423.text: non institutions.  And although I'm not usually a huge fan of financial institutions, you know,

1428.text: being able to make lots of money out of doing not very much, we badly need, as a very high

1435.text: priority in the housing area, to get our major financial institutions, including

1439.text: superannuation funds, involved in large scale provision of housing,

1446.text: And one of the things that that maybe ironically will do, in many cases,

1450.text: is actually provide greater security for tenants than if one's at the mercy of a

1457.text: particular individual investor who has their own changing family or other needs

1462.text: and greater economic vulnerability anyway, to address. And we also lack

1469.text: long term residential leases.  I chaired this, I think it may have been mentioned, a ministerial

1474.text: taskforce on affordable housing 20 years ago for the New South Wales

1477.text: government and we pointed out then that we really needed to move, as an option,

1483.text: to longer term leases; five years, ten year leases as is common in Europe in particular.

1489.text: There'd have to be some adjustment in landlord tenant responsibilities,

1493.text: but it's an example of how in many ways we need to provide a richer spectrum,

1498.text: rather than two ends of the housing options. Rather than the security

1505.text: for life as it were, of either being in public housing or having paid off your home and home ownership,

1508.text: or totally at the mercy of the private rental market with maybe two weeks or four weeks' security.

1513.text: We need to fill in more of the middle points there and one of the ways

1518.text: is to have longer-term residential leases. Now I'll move on to problems with the

1525.text: family location. A key thing here, I think, is the greater needs and options

1533.text: for job mobility.  That, together with the entry of women into the paid workforce has had very

1538.text: profound impacts on the way in which our urban development occurs and on the needs

1549.text: of families and I think it's still not fully realised how much of an impact.

1553.text: In a sense, it's both economic regulation and gendered deregulation. They have worked

1557.text: together to have a huge impact on those patterns. And one of the consequences is

1567.text: that it's made a flexible location; a location from which one will be able

1572.text: of a number of possible work opportunities that one may want

1575.text: or need in future years, has become increasingly important.

1579.text: Instead of staying in the same job for 40 years and getting the gold watch, most people

1583.text: in the future, you know, will go through many jobs in that time.  When you more or less double

1588.text: that because you now have in many cases, two people in that situation in the family,

1593.text: and of course if there are children living at home, adult children living at home,

1596.text: more than that, then you can see why living near - either living near the jobs

1602.text: or living near a very effective transport hub, which will enable you to get in

1608.text: become very important.  And that's a key factor, the key factor in my view,

1612.text: in the gentrification of the inner city suburbs and increasingly around major

1619.text: transport hubs. So location has become hugely more important in the last 30 years

1625.text: because of those two factors.  Greater voluntary or involuntary job

1629.text: mobility and at least two people now in many households needing to have that

1635.text: mobility, rather than you know, just having the one job for one person, the only work travel

1642.text: need will be to go to the same place for 40 years, which was the norm until

1648.text: moderately recently. So more families living further from work options

1655.text: and particularly the lower income families because of the reasons I've mentioned.

1661.text: The people who've got the money move closer to where the jobs or the transport hubs;

1668.text: drive up the house prices, other people have to move out.

1671.text: Now that's been around for a long time, but it's become more acute in the last ten

1675.text: or 20 years.  And amongst other things, that means of course if they can afford it,

1682.text: they need more than the one car.

1688.text: Again, I saw an extraordinary study, I hope it wasn't by the Institute of Family Studies, I don't think it was,

1693.text: which concluded that there wasn't a transport problem,

1699.text: a work travel problem for many people in outer suburbs because they tended to have more

1703.text: cars than people than inner city so they could cope with it.  Now that's really

1707.text: confusing cause and effect. They have to have two cars in many cases to be able

1713.text: to get to a job, but even actually to get to almost anything else in many of those suburbs.

1718.text: And that's why you do have a relatively high ownership. I know Joe Hockey thought that

1722.text: people, poor people didn't drive too much.  Well very poor don't, perhaps, but lower income people do,

1729.text: and in some ways they are lower income because in order to get a job they have to incur those sorts

1735.text: of expenses. Also more complex transport needs in relation to education in childcare

1741.text: and elder care.  This is a huge change.  Again, and again flowing from women's

1745.text: entry into the paid workforce.  The change from the male trip to the place

1755.text: they've worked for 40 years, with the woman it was nearly always, but not always the woman,

1760.text: being at home and doing the smaller trips to school et cetera

1764.text: and there being no need for childcare, has transformed of course.  So that nowadays

1769.text: if you're anything like I was with the two location choices I've made in the last 20 years,

1774.text: hugely influenced by access to childcare and to schools and in one case,

1780.text: almost entirely due in those days to the fact that the local primary had an

1784.text: onsite after school care place.  That's really why we chose the suburb where we live.

1789.text: So these are hugely significant to try to, as many of you will know everyday,

1796.text: these much more complex transport needs than in the past.

1803.text: And also of course, more need to, in many cases, travel to

1808.text: help look after parents who are living longer and often in frail conditions

1816.text: and my generation is starting to experience that very acutely.

1822.text: For many women of roughly my generation of course, it's meant that they have moved
